text: I'm going to switch from talking about
my own story to give you my general
advice for founder's this is very sort
of quick advice the most important
quality you can have is determination
I've seen so many smart and talented
founders fail because they just couldn't
stick with it when things got tough you
can't even imagine what you're going to
have to go through if you you know on
your way to becoming super successful
you need to be able to withstand
rejection people will think your idea is
crazy or they'll think it's lame
investors will say no reporters won't
care and so on three is empathy you need
to be able to talk to your users and
really care about their experience
that's why it's best if you yourself are
a target user of your product then you
can like have a conversation with your
users just by thinking that's true true
for you need to make something people
want a lot it's not enough if they just
want it a little bit they have to want
it enough to actually sign up and to
keep coming back and to tell their
friends about it even when you're just
like this crappy little startup at the
beginning number five is live cheaply
it's the beginning if you don't have a
lot of money you have to live in a way
that buys you more runway it often takes
startups a while figure out exactly what
they should be doing and if you spend
too much money you won't have enough
time for the necessary evolution to
happen I constantly start see startups
with like I think they've almost got it
figured out and then they run out of
money and they die lastly is just focus
I can't stress this one enough it's easy
to waste time on the wrong things
because in a startup there's always 100
things you could be doing right and if
you spend time on those other you know
99 instead of the one optimal thing you
aren't doing the right thing so that was
just like my stew
breathe distilled advice for general for
founders but now I'm going to give you
some advice specifically for women and I
thought about what advice like I'd give
to my own sister if she were starting a
startup and so I wrote a draft and then
I read what I said and after that I
thought oh my god I should just talk
this part out I was terrified to say
anything because things can get pretty
heated out there on the internet on the
topic of women in tech and I was nervous
so I was really like pagan izing over
what I should do like do I keep my life
simple and avoid controversial stuff or
should I really try to help and like
risk getting flamed on the internet
which is like my nightmare
um and then literally in the middle of
this crisis I got this email from a
woman named Vajra who I've never met and
it just like really it hit me I was so
appreciative and I don't know if you can
read it back there but she thanks me for
this blog post that I wrote about what
stops female founders and she's like
thank you for being the finger pointing
to the moon and I like I think I teared
up I was very touched and so I knew what
I had to do okay so in the spirit of
sharing practical information at this
conference I'm going to risk it and
speak candidly okay that's my baby he's
five now so Paul took this picture in
2009 and he jokingly refers to it as
combining work in life which it was and
I have two sons now they're five and two
and based on my own experience I'd say
it's easier to start a start-up before
you have kids okay
shocker I didn't have kids when we first
started YC and I'm honestly not sure if
I would have done it if I had in the
first few years of YC when I was doing
like everything I was working like
really long hours seven days a week it
was all consuming and I just don't know
if I could have worked that many hours
with kids even now when there's a great
team and there
our people that do things at YC I
struggle to manage the balance I mean I
love doing both but I struggle in fact
just yesterday I was really afraid in
this talk and I've got so into it that I
almost forgot to pick up George from
school like I lift something hit me I
was like oh my god and I rushed there
it's definitely possible to combine
having kids and doing a start-up Diane
Greene and Julia hearts have done it and
I hope they'll come out here and give
you good advice on how to do it I'm just
telling you if you have a choice it
would be a lot easier to do before kids
because I found that after I had kids I
didn't want to work 12 hours a day I
wanted to be with them kids pull you in
a different direction than a start-up
does and these two competing forces are
very very powerful so YC has funded
women and men with children of all ages
including newborns and will continue to
do so but for your sake if you have an
option I suggest doing it before kids if
you already have kids start the startup
but know what you're up against and try
to like outsource things that aren't
directly related to your kids like I
mean I use insta car for groceries all
all week long
